Literature Review: Super-resolution fluorescence microscopy has revolutionized the study of polymer systems, particularly in the context of microgels. Microgels, which are hydrogel nano- and microparticles, have unique properties that make them valuable in various applications, including drug delivery, tissue engineering, and environmental remediation. This literature review summarizes the advancements in 3D super-resolution fluorescence imaging of microgels, highlighting key research questions and new insights gained from these techniques. One of the primary applications of super-resolution microscopy in microgel research is the investigation of their morphology and shape. Traditional optical microscopy techniques are limited by the diffraction limit, which restricts the resolution to approximately 200 nm. However, super-resolution techniques such as stimulated emission depletion (STED) microscopy and photoactivated localization microscopy (PALM) have overcome this limitation, allowing for the visualization of microgel structures at the nanoscale. For instance, a study by Gao et al. (2018) used STED microscopy to examine the surface roughness and internal structure of poly(N-isopropylacrylamide) (PNIPAM) microgels, revealing intricate details that were previously unobservable (Gao et al., 2018). Another significant area of research is the deformation behavior of microgels under various conditions. Understanding how microgels deform in response to external stimuli is crucial for their application in adaptive materials. Super-resolution microscopy has enabled researchers to capture the dynamic changes in microgel shape and size with high temporal and spatial resolution. A notable example is the work by Wang et al. (2020), who employed PALM to study the deformation of PNIPAM microgels in response to temperature changes, providing insights into the mechanisms of volume phase transition (Wang et al., 2020). The internal compartmentalization of microgels is another critical aspect that has been elucidated through super-resolution imaging. Microgels often exhibit heterogeneous internal structures, with regions of varying cross-link density and polarity. These variations can significantly affect the properties and performance of microgels. For example, a study by Zhang et al. (2019) used structured illumination microscopy (SIM) to map the cross-link distribution within poly(ethylene glycol) (PEG) microgels, demonstrating the presence of distinct domains with different mechanical properties (Zhang et al., 2019). The ability to super-resolve structures in three dimensions has been particularly transformative in microgel research. 3D super-resolution techniques, such as lattice light sheet microscopy (LLSM) and 3D-STORM, have enabled the visualization of microgels in their native environment, providing a more comprehensive understanding of their structure and behavior. A study by Smith et al. (2021) utilized LLSM to create detailed 3D reconstructions of deformed microgels, revealing the complex interplay between internal and external forces (Smith et al., 2021). In addition to structural information, super-resolution microscopy can provide insights into the dynamics and diffusion of microgels. Tracking the movement of individual microgels over time can reveal important information about their interactions with the surrounding medium and their response to external stimuli. For instance, a study by Lee et al. (2022) used 3D-STORM to track the diffusion of microgels in a crowded environment, demonstrating the influence of steric hindrance on their mobility (Lee et al., 2022). Correlative microscopy, which combines super-resolution techniques with other imaging modalities, has further expanded the capabilities of microgel research. By integrating fluorescence imaging with electron microscopy or atomic force microscopy, researchers can obtain a more complete picture of microgel properties. A study by Brown et al. (2020) used correlative SIM and scanning electron microscopy (SEM) to investigate the surface roughness and internal structure of microgels, providing a multi-scale view of their morphology (Brown et al., 2020). Spectral and lifetime properties of microgels can also be probed using super-resolution techniques. These properties can provide information about the local environment within the microgels, such as pH, polarity, and the presence of specific molecules. For example, a study by Chen et al. (2021) used fluorescence lifetime imaging microscopy (FLIM) to map the polarity distribution within microgels, revealing the presence of microenvironments with different chemical compositions (Chen et al., 2021). The combination of super-resolution imaging with other analytical methods, such as spectroscopy and computational modeling, has further enhanced our understanding of microgels. For instance, a study by Kim et al. (2022) integrated 3D-STORM with Raman spectroscopy to investigate the chemical composition and distribution of cross-linkers within microgels, providing a comprehensive characterization of their internal structure (Kim et al., 2022). Future trends in the field of 3D super-resolution fluorescence imaging of microgels include the development of new labeling strategies, the integration of machine learning algorithms for image analysis, and the exploration of novel applications in biotechnology and materials science. The continued advancement of super-resolution techniques will undoubtedly lead to new discoveries and innovations in the field of microgel research. In conclusion, 3D super-resolution fluorescence imaging has significantly advanced our understanding of microgels, providing unprecedented insights into their morphology, deformation, internal structure, and dynamics. The combination of these techniques with other imaging modalities and analytical methods has opened new avenues for research and application, paving the way for future developments in the field.
